Knocknarea: We've set up tents in the campsite, so take care to rest up in preparation for tomorrow.

Da Vinci: You want me too? Well, as someone on the side of pan-human history—on the side of Chaldea—I can at least offer my opinions.

Da Vinci: Don't worry about me. Go ahead and get some rest, Fujimaru.

Da Vinci: Oh, I'll give you a summary of what we discuss later. Say hi to Mash for me.

Fujimaru 1: Got it. I'll let Oberon know too.

Fujimaru 2: Artoria, will you be okay on your own?

Artoria: Don't worry. Knocknarea may be in charge, but if she gets carried away I'll rein her in immediately.

Artoria: Percival's here too, so I think we can plan out strategies that work for both armies.

Mash: Welcome back, Master. How did the joint planning session with the northern army and the Round Table Army go?

Fujimaru 1: Well, to summarize...

Fujimaru 2: Knocknarea suddenly declared war...

Mash: I see. So Knocknarea asserted that this is a battle between countries.

Mash: The rough plan for the attack on the castle has been decided, and now they're working on the details...is that what's happening?

Fujimaru 1: Yep.

Fujimaru 2: Tomorrow morning, it's war.

Mash: ...

Mash: Our objective is to obtain Rhongomyniad...and to prevent the “collapse” from spreading beyond Britain's lostbelt.

Mash: As long as those two objectives are only fulfilled by defeating Morgan, this battle is unavoidable, but...

Fujimaru 1: Can you fight Morgan, Mash...?

Mash: I'd like it if we could settle everything through discussion...but...

Mash: Queen Morgan has ruled over Britain in the way she believes right for the past 2,000 years.

Mash: That sort of justice and belief can't be shaken with mere words. Most of all, Morgan doesn't want that sort of thing.

Mash: She would only yield her convictions if she were defeated by something greater than herself.

Mash: To grant your desires...your wishes, show your utmost conviction.

Mash: That's the way the savior Tonelico I saw ought to be, strict yet gentle.

Fujimaru 1: ...

Fujimaru 2: (I guess she knew Tonelico...)

Mash: ...And you, Senpai?

Mash: This battle will surely determine the fate of Britain, but...

Mash: It's been 44 days since we left the Storm Border. We're approaching our time limit for the operation.

Mash: If we can investigate Camelot, our mission will be accomplished, but this battle is definitely not something we need to take part in.

Mash: We could take advantage of the confusion during the battle to sneak into Camelot and obtain Rhongomyniad...

Mash: I'm sure Holmes would suggest a plan like that...

Fujimaru 1: —No. I'm fighting.

Fujimaru 1: I promised Artoria I'd help.

Fujimaru 2: I decided that myself.

Mash: That's right...Simply running away was never a choice.

Mash: It's our duty as ones who have seen the death of many Lostbelts, and as people from pan-human history.

Mash: Our hopes as comrades of the Child of Prophecy have journeyed so far.

Mash: Let's take on Queen Morgan with those things in mind. For the future of this beautiful Britain.

--ARROW--

Grimm the Wise: Hey there. Out for a walk by yourself, Fujimaru?

Grimm the Wise: The strategy meeting just came to an end. Now we just have to wait for tomorrow morning.

Grimm the Wise: You and Mash are the vital members of the breakthrough party, so make sure you drive the castle layout into your brain before you get to sleep.

Habetrot: Here you go, a map from Knocknarea. It's a rough layout of the castle town in Camelot.

Habetrot: Back then we were only there for an audience, but the buildings there are pretty tall.

Habetrot: You go down one wrong street and you'll be lost, so be careful. I won't be there to help you this time.

Fujimaru 1: Aren't you going to fight, Habetrot?

Habetrot: The, uh...what was it? Storm Border? I'll stay there until you guys come back.

Habetrot: But I won't fight Morgan. I'll have to hang back and see how the events here play out.

Habetrot: However...

Habetrot: If you're going to fight, I want you to confront her head-on. That way she can't make any excuses.

Habetrot: She's a queen who hates to lose. If you don't do that much, she won't let herself yield.

Habetrot: What about you, Grimm? You gonna go to war with them?

Grimm the Wise: I guess. To be honest, it doesn't really matter to me who wins, but I'll keep Artoria safe.

Grimm the Wise: My mission is to make sure the Fairies of Paradise fulfill their obligations.

Grimm the Wise: Even if Artoria can't beat Morgan, as long as she stays alive then she can pull through.

Fujimaru 1: Artoria will win.

Fujimaru 2: The prophecy says she'll become the true king.

Habetrot: Yeah, that's what Ainsel said, wasn't it?

Habetrot: “Guided by the Staff of Selection, watched over by the foreign traveller, the child of salvation will reach the throne. ”

Habetrot: “The true king takes their place on the throne. A bloodstained crown presented. ”

Habetrot: “Let the six bells toll in demonstration. Make way for the true king. ”

Habetrot: So far it's played out exactly as stated.

Habetrot: The six bells have rung, the foreign traveller is watching, and the throne will finally be in reach tomorrow.

Habetrot: As far as I can tell, Artoria and Morgan's Saint Graphs are equally matched.

Habetrot: They have differences in the company they keep, but that's about even too. All that's left is to do their best tomorrow...still...

Habetrot: That part about the “bloodstained crown” is in pretty poor taste...it's talking about a crown soaked in Morgan's blood.

Habetrot: Proposing that's how the Child of Prophecy wins...damned Ainsel, surely you could have put it better.

Habetrot: Well, I guess Morgan has been doing as much to Britain though...

Habetrot: ...

Grimm the Wise: ...

Grimm the Wise: Oh, right. Fujimaru, can you bring Percival a message for me?

Grimm the Wise: I'm carving runes into the shields of the Round Table Army's soldiers too, but even I have my limits.

Grimm the Wise: Ask him to gather a hundred of his best men. He should be in the officer's tent.

Fujimaru 1: Got it.

Fujimaru 2: Be nice to Habetrot, now.

Grimm the Wise: Hey, I've known her since the first Grimm! I'll keep an eye on her, make sure she doesn't do anything crazy!

Percival: ...

Narration: Love is an inexplicable thing in this world.

Narration: Poets sing that love is fate itself. That it is joy. That it is death.

Narration: Those without love are happy in a way, and those with are unhappy in a way.

Narration: When I was a child, I didn't know what that meant.

Narration: I believed that love was simple, that loving and being loved were all it took to be happy.

Narration: The place I was brought to after being bought from the farm was a lush, verdant city.

Narration: I lived without hardship in an educational facility alongside other children, purchased much like myself.

Narration: The facility was built at the suggestion of a fairy.

Narration: “Well, why don't we raise one personally? ”

Narration: A school not to raise fairy knights, but human ones.

Narration: The one appointed its director...was the head of the Fang Clan.

Narration: He only appeared a few times, but each time he said to the children:

Narration: “We bought all the children born that year. There are no longer any other candidates. ”

Narration: “If you show no aptitude by the time you come of age, this plan will have failed. Your days may be taxing, but I'm counting on you. ”

Narration: The head of the Fang Clan may have been rough in nature, but he was neither cruel nor inhumane.

Narration: “Why did I get into the restaurant business? Hrm. Well, I suppose I can tell you. ”

Narration: “We of the Fang Clan are prone to savagery. Once our tempers flare, quenching them is difficult. ”

Narration: “Because of that, we once committed a grave sin. An entire clan was destroyed for trivial reasons. ”

Narration: “The Fang Clan require manners. They must also regulate their tastes. A vegetable diet is better than a meat one. ”

Narration: “However, that was not a sin that can be atoned for...I would at least like to attempt to avoid repeating our mistakes. ”

Narration: Although we didn't respect him, because he too was suffering due to his own karma, neither did we hate him.

Narration: The days of training continued.

Narration: One by one, children dropped out and were taken as slaves by other fairies.

Narration: I stayed behind since I was blessed with a strong physique. And then...

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Yes. See how hot your left arm is now? That's a magic circuit. Your special talent, Percival.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Even humans can generate magical energy. After that, it all comes down to how you use it. Just try to copy me.

Narration: Then came the Knight of the Lake, the strongest and most gentle in all of Britain.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: You don't have to rush. I'm here for you, Percival.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Woodwose won't be coming anymore. His project is done.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: So take your time. Grow up slowly.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Don't be rash. Don't get hurt or anything else. And don't get into any funny business I don't know about.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: My first student. My first child. My first little brother. My first friend.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: My—treasured Percival. Please, be sure to grow up strong.

Narration: Back then, that was the “love” I knew.

Narration: I was content to just be loved.

Narration: I was more than happy to live up to those expectations.

Narration: But...as I grew older, I came to see a little more of the world.

Narration: Little by little, I came to see things my child self hadn't.

Fairy: Ooh, listen to this, Mélusine...! It's awful, just simply awful...!

Fairy: Bones and the others do nothing but harass us, even though everybody worked so hard for the manor...

Fairy: Their own manor is doing so well, so I can see why they're so confident, but...

Fairy: It's nothing but baseless slander...and now he's even harassing the humans who work in the manor...

Fairy: I'm worried...Bones and his friends are thugs, aren't they? If they were to do something...

Fairy: Aah, I feel like I'll break apart just thinking about it...are my wings still sparkling?

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Of course...don't worry. I'll take care of all your problems.

Narration: The love that I knew, what was directed at me, was not love at all.

Narration: That was charity.

Narration: Love was fate, joy, and death. It was a curse that you couldn't do anything about.

Narration: It was a mistake. I knew it was all a mistake.

Narration: Love obscures your better judgement. It turns wise men into fools. Good men into villains.

Narration: Something beautiful will lose its form.

Narration: You know you're just being used, but you depend on that love.

Narration: —The happiness that was originally promised. Even the future that was suitable for her was stolen away.

Mélusine: Uuh...uuu. . aah...aah...

Mélusine: aaah...aaaah...!

Narration: That day, I heard the wails and felt as if my soul was cracking apart.

Narration: It was the night I broke the rules and headed to the cathedral to convey the news that I had been granted the Spear of Selection.

Narration: There, I saw her despair over her own foolishness.

Narration: I couldn't call out to her or help her. I was only a ten-year-old boy.

Narration: That was why I thought so hard about growing up as fast as I could.

Narration: I'd understand when I grew up. I'd be able to break that awful curse.

Percival as a Young Boy: —That's it. I'm going to save her.

Narration: I may be the commander of the Round Table Army, but I'm not that great a person. The only way to free her is to defeat the Queen.

Narration: I was never of a mind to go to war for Britain's sake.

Narration: I only had one wish. No matter how selfish that love was, that was all.

Percival: —I understand, Gareth. My childish selfishness is over.

Percival: Your spear will definitely reach them. For the sake of your wish to protect Britain.

Fujimaru 1: Sorry for disturbing you.

Fujimaru 2: Percival, are you in here?

Percival: Oh, what is it, Fujimaru? Is there something you need from me?

Percival: From Grimm? A hundred of our best? I see.

Percival: I'll start talking to them right away. Thanks for your trouble.

Fujimaru 1: What is it...?

Fujimaru 2: Are you okay...?

Percival: You saw through my lack of enthusiasm, huh...you're right, I was scolded for not concentrating on the meeting earlier as well.

Percival: But I've already sorted through it. I've decided on what I need to do.

Percival: In this moment, I am Percival of the Round Table Army. I have a treasured objective and a treasured wish.

Percival: Right now, I only fight for what should be. Please let Artoria know that too.

Percival: I'm sure she would be able to see right through me, either way...

Fujimaru 1: ...?

Fujimaru 2: (I see...Percival is still...)

Percival: Tomorrow is the decisive battle with Her Majesty. We'll inevitably have a confrontation with Fairy Knight Lancelot.

Percival: As Knight Commander of the Round Table Army, please leave her to me.

Percival: Even should I lose—I'll keep her occupied until the battle is over.

Fujimaru 1: Is that what you want, Percival...?

Percival: It is. The central figures in this war are Artoria and Knocknarea. The prophecy doesn't even mention me.

Percival: In the end, I'm just a child who never understood love...

--ARROW--

Fujimaru 1: Just the two of you?

Fujimaru 2: Where's Artoria?

Senji Muramasa: Artoria was here a while ago. She went outside the encampment to get some air.

Da Vinci: It'd be rash to act alone while in front of the enemy lines. But, Artoria would have no problems holding off a Fairy Knight the way she is now.

Da Vinci: It's still a concern why she had to go all the way out there. I guess she's tired of being in so big a group.

Senji Muramasa: Well, come now, she's just not so good with crowds, is she?

Senji Muramasa: Kind of like how I'm not good with fairies. Humans here don't seem great with them either.

Attention! Crucial Dialogue Select

Fujimaru 1: You think so?

Fujimaru 2: Because Artoria can see through other people's lies...?

Da Vinci: Is that how she appears to you, Muramasa? True, she seems a little uncomfortable.

Da Vinci: I just try not to mind other people's business more than my own. It beats acting stuck-up.

Da Vinci: After all, and this stays between us, isn't Artoria really dangerous at this point? She's on the level of a Lostbelt King.

Da Vinci: If she turned to evil in a fit of rage, don't you think we'd all be destroyed?

Da Vinci: Should that ever happen, I'll make Muramasa into a decoy while the rest of us hightail it. Have fun!

Senji Muramasa: We'll go to the other side together if that happens. Don't expect a boost across the Sanzu from me, got it?

Da Vinci: Hm? Can she see through other's lies?

Senji Muramasa: That'd be Fairy Eyes, I suppose...

Senji Muramasa: “By nature, fairies cannot be lied to. It's a result of them actually seeing emotions. ”

Senji Muramasa: That's how Muryan put it. Though, she herself seemed to have a bit of that power in her.

Da Vinci: Hold on. Ever since they started mimicking human culture...

Da Vinci: Oberon said that the Mystery of Fairy Eyes abated in Britain's fairies.

Da Vinci: I get it, Artoria isn't a fairy native to Britain. She's from Avalon, so—

Senji Muramasa: She sees lies, and knows other people's true feelings. Or maybe things even more essential than that.

Senji Muramasa: The nature of evil, causality, and karma. I've spent my own life pondering such things.

Senji Muramasa: Being able to see karma has a terrible—no, a miserable lot in life.

Senji Muramasa: The reason for fairies disappearing from pan-human history may be attributed to the development of civilization.

Senji Muramasa: But in fact, it's gotta be because human malice is so unbearable to watch.

Senji Muramasa: We invent languages, start learning, and spread knowledge from the upper to lower classes.

Senji Muramasa: That's how humans gain wisdom. At the same time, we gained powers of deception through words, speaking falsely, hiding our true intentions.

Senji Muramasa: The fairies couldn't take it, so they stopped associating with humans.

Senji Muramasa: And here in this Lostbelt, fairies started to hide their intentions like humans do.

Senji Muramasa: Only two sensed the ugliness in being shown lies.

Senji Muramasa: Artoria and Morgan were the only ones pan-human history would consider actual fairies.

Da Vinci: I see...it's one thing to see through a lie, and another to look upon it directly.

Da Vinci: There are times where we're fine with being fooled, even if we know it's a lie. We can close our eyes in order to make the conversation go smoothly.

Da Vinci: But those with Fairy Eyes can't close them off. They have no choice but to be confronted by the lie and our true intent.

Fujimaru 1: If you only stuck with honest people...

Fujimaru 2: If lies were forbidden...

Da Vinci: That still wouldn't solve the problem. Every honest person has a disparity between their words and thoughts.

Da Vinci: It's still fine to lie in order to undermine someone. You can cope with that if you know what you're doing.

Da Vinci: But for those who can see, the hardest thing is lying out of concern for others.

Da Vinci: Even if you're doing it in good faith, it's a falsehood.

Da Vinci: So even compassion and consideration will appear corrupted to Fairy Eyes...

Da Vinci: For the Fairies of Paradise, Britain at present is no different from human society.

Da Vinci: Would they want to save a Britain like that...?

Senji Muramasa: I think she might. The girl is pretty hardcore in that regard.

Senji Muramasa: That she hasn't run away yet is the best proof of that. I can't tell what makes her so pigheaded—

Senji Muramasa: But that's the kind of steel that never bends until the end! One way or another, she lives by her faith in you brats!

Senji Muramasa: But you never know what life—even as a Servant—has in store for you, right?

Senji Muramasa: I wanted to pay back the debt for saving my life and get back to the Alien God...

Senji Muramasa: Yet things went on longer than expected.

Senji Muramasa: The story kept going, and going. And before I knew it, we're half a day from attacking the castle.

Senji Muramasa: And with the Master from Chaldea in tow. I wonder how that was meant to be.

Da Vinci: I'll say. It's a great situation, if you ask me.

Da Vinci: I included it in my reports, but I'm sure Director Gordolf is at his wit's end.

Fujimaru 1: Why don't you just join us?

Senji Muramasa: Yeah, that wouldn't be a bad idea!

Fujimaru 1: Could you!?

Senji Muramasa: Yeah, I could. The Alien God only summoned me as a Servant to play a particular role.

Senji Muramasa: “With the eye of the strongest on you, there is no cause for discord. Therefore, you will not betray us. ”

Senji Muramasa: What the right job for you is, your likes and dislikes, and all that...I don't really understand the subtleties of humanity.

Senji Muramasa: It all comes down to a matter of loss or gain...that's how it used to be, at least.

Senji Muramasa: Well, I'll leave that to the other Muramasa. The one you actually formed a connection with.

Fujimaru 1: That's too bad...

Senji Muramasa: Yeah. You better treasure the way this feels, kid. These were some good talks, not having to lie or put on pretense.

Senji Muramasa: The reason Artoria was able to press on this far on her journey was because you have that way about you.

Artoria: Ahhhh, I'm so tired...

Artoria: Do you have to issue orders to every individual soldier, Knocknarea?

Artoria: That kind of stuff ought to be entrusted to their troop leaders.

Artoria: Northern fairies don't think too hard, so the brainwork is best left to those who do.

Artoria: But that's what makes them honest and uniform in personality. They're filled with loyalty to her.

Artoria: The people of the Round Table Army have recovered. Tomorrow's battle is looking like—

Oberon: Everything will go just as the prophecy foretold. Morgan will be defeated without any sacrifices.

Oberon: The pilgrimage went well. No companions departed the group.

Oberon: Likewise, the rebel army is in perfect shape. Nobody is hiding anything, unlike the queen's army.

Oberon: Everything ought to end happily ever after. Don't you agree, Artoria?

Artoria: ...

Oberon: You're worried about Gareth, I guess. Her end was written in the prophecy.

Oberon: “The round fortress shall burn out, the bell of the waters shall be revealed. ”

Oberon: It wasn't your fault that it happened, or that she left you. That's just the way it had to be.

Artoria: Do you really think so...?

Oberon: Of course. Gareth hardly comes to mind any other way.

Artoria: I don't mean about Gareth. You just said “without any sacrifices. ”

Artoria: The rebel army has little chance of winning...everyone in the Round Table Army, humans in particular, will die in the battle.

Artoria: I know this, but you're assuring me there'll be no sacrifices.

Artoria: And also, “unlike the queen's army”.

Artoria: You've actually known Knocknarea for a long time now, Oberon.

Artoria: When she caught us on our way back from the royal audience, you were pretending you'd never met before.

Oberon: Yes, well, actually...

Oberon: You wouldn't have trusted me if you'd known I was on good terms with Knocknarea, would you?

Artoria: Not just that, either.

Artoria: When we saw Mash for the first time in Norwich...

Fujimaru: That's Mash—!

Oberon: What—!?

Artoria: —

Artoria: You knew about her. You knew, and pretended to see her for the first time.

Artoria: You knew all along that Mash was in Sheffield, but kept silent.

Artoria: Because Fujimaru would've gone there after her, so you hid it from [♂ him /♀ her] to avoid that.

Oberon: Yes, well, actually...

Oberon: That wouldn't have fit in with Fujimaru's mission from Chaldea.

Oberon: I wanted [♂ him /♀ her] to support the Child of Prophecy by [♂ his /♀ her] own will.

Oberon: I'll admit that I was dishonest.

Oberon: Even taking into account that Mash is a powerful Fairy Knight, it was dangerous to go up north on your own.

Artoria: And...

Oberon: And what?

Oberon: That's why I'm so much more invested in Britain than I probably should be, because they're here.

Oberon: It's ridiculous to think that because they're worthless, they can't do anything. The helpless ones were the only ones to help me.

Oberon: So I gotta return the favor☆ That's why I'm working so hard to overthrow Morgan.

Artoria: And...you were somewhere else on the morning of the battle with Woodwose's army.

Artoria: They didn't have any reinforcements from the Queen at the time. We might have won, but...

Artoria: That too was the result of something you did. You come off—

Artoria: You come off as honest and sincere, but you don't tell the truth. You leave out important details from others.

Artoria: Why is that? Why have you lied so many times?

Artoria: Maybe you don't—you don't really want to defeat Morgan, do you?

Oberon: —

Oberon: That isn't true at all. No other fairy has done more to oppose Morgan than I have.

Oberon: I will devote my very being to overthrow the Fairy Kingdom, even if it means lying. And what's more—

Oberon: You've been telling lies too, Artoria.

Oberon: The reasons for coming all this way. I mean, your motives for saving Britain.

Oberon: It's not just me. Fujimaru has an inkling as well.

Oberon: You weren't fighting for the humans, or for fairies, or any reason in particular.

Oberon: Your true feelings lie elsewhere. You just don't talk about it.

Artoria: That's a ridiculous thing to say...

Artoria: I'm the Fairy of Paradise, sent to save Britain.

Oberon: That's your guilt talking. In the first place, what does Britain's salvation mean to you?

Oberon: Muramasa told me something.

Oberon: “All the fairies are seeking forgiveness. They all want to be destroyed. ”

Oberon: No matter what the city or who the fairy, they all have the same wish at the bottom of their hearts.

Artoria: Muramasa said that...?

Oberon: He doesn't have Fairy Eyes like you and I do, though. I'm sure it's just a sensitivity to heartache.

Oberon: Artoria. That's the source of your hesitation, isn't it?

Oberon: You don't bring up the crucial facts, because there's no reason to do so.

Oberon: That's how it is for me. If it's necessary for bringing down Morgan, we have to do things we otherwise wouldn't.

Oberon: Let's leave off here for now. Tomorrow's battle will finish this, once and for all.

Oberon: I'm sure the time will come when we can both reveal the important things we've been hiding.

Oberon: And isn't that what the pilgrimage was all about?

Oberon: Hey, why not confide in them? They might just surprise you by laughing it off.

--ARROW--

Barghest: It seems Knocknarea and the Round Table Army have already joined up.

Barghest: There's nothing we can do to prevent their alliance...their common goal is very clear.

Barghest: The blessings of the Child of Prophecy combined with the Fairy Territory of the King's Clan. They might stand on par with us in terms of military strength.

Barghest: I'm sure Her Majesty intends to crush them head on, but there are scenarios where that may backfire.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: With the same number of troops, we'll come out victorious as long as you and I are present.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: In fact, that's assured if we attacked on our own. Whether the Queen's knights participate makes no difference.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I could destroy the Knocknarean force alone, and likewise, you could rout the Round Table Army.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: There's no point in waiting until morning, and no reason to meet them in a fair battle.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The Foreign Magus. Galahad. Two Servants. Percival.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: That's all that needs our attention. But I can settle things with them by myself.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Their abilities are satisfactory, but compatibility trumps all. Not one of them can fight in the air.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The only ones who can contend with me are Her Majesty Morgan, and you with your enlarged fairy body.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: If they were going to challenge Camelot, they should've brought double the troops.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: But the Salisbury soldiers who sympathized with the rebels have just crossed over to the western plains.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The Fang Clan, which could've been a secret weapon, have disappeared. I can only imagine banished.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Their chances are overvalued. Ainsel's prophecy is averted. The rebellion ends here.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Unless...they have specimens on their side able to rival us Fairy Knights.

Barghest: I guess you're right...they don't have any Fairy Knights.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Her Majesty has ordered us to slay only the troops who enter the castle.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I'm to do laps in the sky and pick off soldiers who try to scale the city walls.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Her Majesty's knights are stationed in the castle town, but they won't get a chance to fight.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The main gate is your domain, Barghest. Nothing will get past you.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I wish I could send them a few flowers out of sympathy, but reality is harsh.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I suppose the last battle of the Fairy Kingdom will end quietly and uneventfully.

Barghest: The last, huh...? Sure, there won't ever be another rebellion on this scale again.

Barghest: But the Calamities won't quit, and Her Majesty has no intention of stopping the Great Calamity.

Barghest: The victory gained by us Fairy Knights means most every fairy in Britain will die off.

Barghest: Don't you find that hollow? What's the purpose of even winning this battle?

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I'm surprised...I thought you didn't think about things that way.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Woodwose called fighting instinctive, and that the Fang Clan took joy in struggling against powerful foes.

Barghest: I don't deny it...I also possess the nature of a bloodthirsty beast.

Barghest: I'm no different from Baobhan Sith in that I can't help but trample over the weak.

Barghest: But that's my personal issue, and no concern for Britain as a whole.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I see. You became a Fairy Knight to protect Britain, didn't you?

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Sorry, but I'm different. Her Majesty's gifted name is but a shackle on me.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I am a combat aircraft. Human swordplay is a bothersome distraction.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Yet I received the title of Fairy Knight because I fit the part of Lancelot.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: It was about 100 years ago that my body showed signs of irregularity.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: My love for her kept me contained, but that can't last forever either.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: It was Her Majesty that saved me from such a fate. Taking the name of a Fairy Knight keeps me from returning to that state.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: It's not for Britain that I obey, but to maintain my form.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: So I don't quite understand what you've told me...no, I do, but I don't care to think about it.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Because I have something else that's more important to me.

Barghest: More important to you than Britain...?

Barghest: (I have something like that myself...Adonis...at least, until he dies of natural causes...)

Fairy Knight Lancelot: You don't have anything like that, do you? That's what I envy about you.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Her Majesty Morgan is one who knows no love, but her trust in you is steadfast.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: However many blunders you commit, she will always call upon you. I can see why Woodwose was jealous.

Barghest: Her Majesty knows no love...?

Barghest: No...I supposed she doesn't. Her love is focused on the Fairy Kingdom.

Barghest: I am also indebted to Her Majesty. Without the gifted name of the Fairy Knight, I wouldn't be able to exist today.

Barghest: I possess Her Majesty's favor. Even if it's to control me, it is still an obligation.

Barghest: But...

Barghest: (I can accept no further rewards. Not if I want to protect Britain...and his future. )

Baobhan Sith: Night...it's night...somebody get...get me some light...

Baobhan Sith: I have a ball...to attend...and just the dress...to wear...

Baobhan Sith: Is anyone...there...? ...Anyone...there...?

Baobhan Sith: Oh...forgive me...forgive me, Mother...

Baobhan Sith: It wasn't my fault...I didn't want to...

Baobhan Sith: But...My Lord wanted to see...what a moving corpse looked like...

Baobhan Sith: That's the only...reason I...sucked their blood...

Baobhan Sith: And he was so...amused by the...number we had...in the crypt...

Baobhan Sith: To heaving...yes...full to heaving, of course it would be!

Baobhan Sith: Help me, help me, somebody help me! Help them, help them all!

Baobhan Sith: I can't do anything else. There's nothing else I can do!

Baobhan Sith: I didn't have anything to begin with, so nobody would help me!

Baobhan Sith: No power, no talents, no friends!

Baobhan Sith: Aa—aaaaaaaah! If Mother abandons me, I'm as good as nothing...!

Watchtower Fairy A: There she goes again...Fairy Knight Tristan is finally on her last legs.

Watchtower Fairy A: Defeated by the Child of Prophecy, stripped of her Fairy Knight name, and Beryl Gut has disappeared.

Watchtower Fairy A: Her last light of hope from Her Majesty's favors has finally been snuffed out. I've been ordered to seal the door with wax tomorrow.

Watchtower Fairy A: I suppose execution is too much of a bother. Fairy Knight Tristan will vanish without a trace.

Watchtower Fairy B: Is that so bad? It's a fitting end for the single most hated figure in Britain.

Watchtower Fairy B: She's murdered more than her share of fairies. If I could, I'd snuff her out personally.

Watchtower Fairy A: Leave it be. She's a rotting mess that can't even move anymore. Leave her be and let time take her.

Watchtower Fairy A: Make one false move and you'll catch a curse. She's not worth the trouble of killing.

Watchtower Fairy B: Hmm, you might be right. At any rate, we'll be taking charge of a former princess.

Watchtower Fairy A: Who's there!? Her Majesty has ordered that no one may visit—Oh, you are—

Fairies on Watch: Ga—ahh—

Spriggan: —Hm, I hadn't heard there would be soldiers on watch.

Spriggan: I've made you do something so trifling. Though, I'm sure they'd have found their next generation soon enough.

Escorting Soldier: There's a key on the sentry's body. I will open the door. Are you sure about this?

Spriggan: Of course, I'm told she's bedridden. Carry her with respect.

Spriggan: I don't mind if you're forced to be a little rough with her. There's little time to waste.

Escorting Soldier: Yes, sir. Alright, let's do this.

Spriggan: To say she's not worth the trouble of killing. That's a very vulgar statement that one of them made.

Spriggan: Most things have no value in the first place. It's only a matter of whether you should discard them or not.

Spriggan: The worth is what you make of it—any old junk can have its use.

I：???: Uh...uuh...waAAh...

I：???: Must make sure...I have...to ask...

I：???: Your...Majesty.... Queen...Morgan...

I：???: It can't...have been...true...not...by any...

Aurora: Oh, how wonderful...! You're still alive, you uncompromising beast!

Aurora: I could hardly believe my ears when Spriggan called me to ask if I would hide you.

Aurora: Hehe, I can't believe you're really alive!

Aurora: Coral, he needs medical attention! Let's use the most precious magic dust we have!

Woodwose: Ahh...my thanks, Aurora...you are...truly...a lovely...fairy...

Woodwose: I am ashamed...to have ever doubted you...ungh...ah...aah, ah...

Coral: It's no good...I can't get the hole in his chest to close...and the magic dust has run out...

Coral: Not to mention, the battle ended in victory for the Round Table Army. For us to shelter Lord Woodwose...

Aurora: Don't give up. Get medicine from all over the city. It's of no concern who won the battle.

Aurora: With the battle already over, we cannot just let him die.

Aurora: Yes, isn't that so...? He's the proud head of the Fang Clan.

Aurora: I will not let him die in misery, after all he did to protect Britain for centuries.

Woodwose: Aurora...Aurora...ugh...I've made...such a mistake...

Woodwose: If I had only listened...to your voice...from the beginning—

Aurora: Say no more. You should rest, Woodwose. Oh, but it's so hard to believe...

Aurora: I wanted to believe that it was only gossip among the fairies...that Her Majesty had abandoned the Fang Clan...

Woodwose: Gossip...gossip...Aurora...Her Majesty has done...what?

Aurora: Oh, poor Woodwose...of course you wouldn't know...

Aurora: Your reinforcements were never sent to begin with.

Aurora: Her Majesty hated the Fang Clan for consuming so many humans. She was going to let you wipe each other out in the battle.

Aurora: Her Majesty only values the Fairy Knights. She's not even trying to find your body.

Aurora: I do hate to say this, but...

Aurora: You've been abandoned, Woodwose, like a useless, outdated watchdog.

Woodwose: I can't believe it...I won't believe it...I will not...

Woodwose: Your...Majesty...it cannot be...it cannot...

Woodwose: That you never...not once...loved the Fang Clan's loyalty...or devotion...

Woodwose: I have to...make sure...

Woodwose: I will make sure...even if it kills me...

--ARROW--

Note: Male Player

Oberon: Oh dear, what brings you outside the encampment? Too worked up to sleep?

Note: Female Player

Oberon: Oh dear, even if the encampment's close by it doesn't mean a young girl ought to be wandering about alone.

Oberon: What's the matter? Too nervous to sleep?

Note: Branch End

Fujimaru 1: Same to you, Oberon. What are you doing here?

Oberon: Having a heart-to-heart with Artoria. She still seemed lost, you see.

Oberon: Even if our troops match theirs, they still have the Fairy Knights. If we let up, we'll end up losing.

Oberon: That's why I gave her a pep talk!

Oberon: “Artoria, did you know that the name King Arthur means king of bears!? ”

Oberon: Something like that☆

Fujimaru 1: I can just imagine Artoria's face...

Fujimaru 2: Or rather, I can already see it...

Oberon: She hates to lose, you see. So getting her fired up was more effective than telling her off.

Oberon: In a few more hours, the curtain of night will lift. When the morning lark sings, the final battle will begin.

Oberon: I've done everything I can. There's nothing more I can do.

Oberon: Well...I have my own regrets, though.

Oberon: I fluttered about here and there, but in the end, I ran out of time. I couldn't find what I was looking for.

Attention! Crucial Dialogue Select

Fujimaru 1: What were you looking for again?

Oberon: I speak of a star. A star beyond reach.

Fujimaru 2: Even though you said she's not here?

Oberon: Should you not search for something just because it doesn't exist? You've got it the other way around, Fujimaru.

Oberon: It is because it doesn't exist that we should search for it. It's why we yearn for it.

Oberon: For me, my queen Titania is such an existence. Akin to the stars shining in the sky.

Oberon: For the likes of us, struggling on the ground, it may be eternally unattainable.

Oberon: Well, let's leave my story for another time. To be honest, I'm not used to opening my heart like this.

Oberon: You should head back to the tent and get some rest. I can prepare some magical dust for you if you can't sleep, you know?

Oberon: I'm no use in combat but putting someone to sleep is my forte. I won't even lose to the incubus Merlin.

Fujimaru 1: I might just be imagining things, but...

Oberon: Hmm? What might be on your mind?

Fujimaru 1: Oberon, you always seem angry.

Oberon: Yeah, I guess.

Oberon: Truth be told, I've been sulking ever since I heard that you guys have been wiping Lostbelts out.

Oberon: Not directed at you. At those who will know of your story afterwards.

Oberon: It's just the way it's always been. All events invariably become a “tale” for all except the parties involved.

Oberon: Once decades have passed, your quest will end up as merely another “report”.

Oberon: For those who peruse it, it's just seems like someone else's problem. A lesson to be learned. I'd hate that.

Oberon: Half of the Fairy King Oberon was borne of a story.

Oberon: That's why my feelings are divided.

Oberon: The part of me that longs for the proper form of Britain as a Heroic Spirit of pan-human history.

Oberon: And the part of me that wishes to continue this story as a fictional character.

Oberon: Those two parts are still at odds, even now.

Oberon: There is no problem with wiping out Lostbelts for the sake of pan-human history. We're basically there already.

Oberon: But, it's hard to bear the thought of it being forgotten by future generations.

Oberon: I don't want them to think that “their disappearance was a matter of course”.

Oberon: I want them to know that it had meaning, even if it ends halfway through.

Oberon: Well, that's just the ego of the parties involved for you, though.

Oberon: Humans have made progress by viewing the past as a record. You can't just “stick to the same values” forever.

Oberon: That's what “once upon a time” means. The word “old-fashioned” is also proof that we've moved forward.

Fujimaru 1: Do you loathe Morgan, Oberon...?

Oberon: I am her enemy, but I don't loathe her. I've never even met her.

Oberon: But...let's see. The story of this Fairy Kingdom isn't a bad one.

Oberon: To put it into words, the Queen's Calendar is a fairy tale crafted by Morgan.

Oberon: It's the incarnation of the dream she wished for, believed in, and dedicated her whole being to realize.

Oberon: I pay tribute to the effort, regardless of whether it happens to be a masterpiece or mediocre.

Oberon: That is exactly why I will also dedicate my whole being to defeat Morgan.

Oberon: As a resident of the same fairy tale world, I don't want her final act to be a half-baked one.

Oberon: Well, I'd lose if I don't give it my all, so it's not exactly my place to be talking about being half-baked, is it?

Oberon: I'll leave Artoria in your hands, Fujimaru. I believe I've already said it earlier, but my role has reached its end.

Oberon: From here on out, it's your fight. Please do show me a spectacular victory before I leave.

# Section 24: Morgan

Knocknarea: Daybreak comes! All units, form up!

Knocknarea: The Round Table, gathered here under the Child of Prophecy...The northern fairies, my very hands and feet...

Knocknarea: And volunteers from every corner of the land! We are now one army, united in purpose!

Knocknarea: Our name is the New Queen's Army!

Knocknarea: We are comrades in arms for the sake of building a new Britain to welcome the “true king” heralded in Ainsel's prophecy!

Knocknarea: You there, Fujimaru! You look like you're waiting for the other shoe to drop!

Knocknarea: No word of surrender has come from Camelot. Our pompous Queen is saying: “come and get me! ”

Knocknarea: That is exactly what I want! I've been waiting 100 years for this!

Knocknarea: Are you all ready to fight, to give your lives? Let's do this once and for all!

Knocknarea: Queen Morgan is our enemy, and Camelot is to fall! All troops, march! We'll bring down the main gate first!

Fujimaru 1: Here we are...

Fujimaru 2: Our situation is...

Mash: The first division of the Round Table Army includes Artoria, Master Fujimaru, and Da Vinci.

Mash: The second division includes Muramasa and Grimm.

Mash: Knocknarea's main camp stands at the tail end of our lines,

Mash: and is housing Rab-bit and Habetrot, who have declined to participate in the battle.

Mash: I, Mash Kyrielight, have deployed with Master to the first division.

Da Vinci: Right. Muramasa and Grimm seem much stronger when paired together.

Da Vinci: I was approached to bolster the strength of the second division, which will be drawing fire. Oh, speaking of which...

Round Table Army Soldier: Greetings to you, Commander Percival. We of the second division will now begin our march.

Percival: Yes. As planned, you'll be the diversionary force that attacks the castle walls. We in the first division will escort the Giant Corps.

Percival: Your unit will be isolated. If the battle is prolonged, you risk being trampled.

Percival: Attack the walls as best you can, but take no needless risks.

Percival: Once the main gate opens, you'll fall back to the base camp and await orders from Knocknarea.

Round Table Army Soldier: Yes, sir! Leave it to us! We'll see to it that our mission is accomplished!

Round Table Army Soldier: Child of Prophecy, Foreign Magus–pardon me, Lady Artoria and Fujimaru.

Round Table Army Soldier: Please keep yourselves safe, and take care of the commander.

Percival: We should begin our march too.

Percival: The soldiers of the Queen's army are stationed at the main gate. Fairy Knight Barghest is in command.

Percival: Knocknarea's giant corp will be breaking through the gate. Our role is to escort them there.

Percival: It will be necessary to deal with both the Queen's army and Barghest.

Percival: Artoria will stand in the vanguard, and pass her magecraft's blessings among the whole force.

Percival: Fujimaru will use [♂ his /♀ her] formidable powers to combat the Queen's knights, and...

Da Vinci: Barghest is our opponent.

Fujimaru 1: But we have a secret pact with Barghest.

Da Vinci: Of course. We won't be fighting her.

Da Vinci: As per our pact at Manchester, she'll declare her support for the Child of Prophecy as soon as we pass through the main gate.

Artoria: But we never agreed to a common strategy.

Artoria: As far as she's concerned, she will stay an honest knight to Morgan until the gate actually falls.

Artoria: First we clear a path to the main gate. Afterwards, we keep the eyesore Barghest contained.

Artoria: Is that what you had in mind, Da Vinci?

Da Vinci: Right. Barghest will be the last one to realize that you're in the vanguard.

Da Vinci: We're all well aware of the risks, so let's confront them head on.

Da Vinci: The surroundings are still just as we confirmed before dawn. Isn't it nice, Fujimaru?

Fujimaru 1: Don't worry, I know it all by heart.

Fujimaru 2: It comes down to how quickly we pass the main gate, right?

Oberon: I'm shocked. So you're saying Barghest is going to betray them for us?

Artoria: Oberon!?

Percival: Oberon!? Are you going into battle as well!?

Oberon: Yeah. This is the final battle. Even in the worst case, you won't be needing a scout anymore.

Oberon: Besides, I've had enough of being left out. I can be of some use on the battlefield.

Oberon: More importantly, you guys were negotiating with Barghest?

Fujimaru 1: Right, when we were in the Lake District...

Oberon: Ahh...I see, that fits the timing. No wasted moves there, I'd say.

Fujimaru 2: Huh? Didn't Da Vinci fill you in?

Da Vinci: Me? Wasn't it you or Artoria who were going to?

Artoria: It wasn't me. Fujimaru said [♂ he /♀ she]'d do it.

Fujimaru 1: No, Artoria. You said you would!

Fujimaru 2: (That face...I completely forgot how it looked...! )

Oberon: Wow...you really are completely lost without blatant context to guide you, Artoria.

Oberon: What, did the bells only strengthen your magical energy? Is there anything that will improve that scatterbrained personality of yours?

Artoria: W-well...I would rather not think about any good times spent with Bageko...

Oberon: Seems the march has already begun...There's no use talking about what's already done.

Oberon: But if Barghest is with us, the circumstances of Camelot's capture will change quite a bit.

Oberon: With any luck, the lie will become truth.

Fujimaru 1: Hm? What's that?

Oberon: “Victory without sacrifices. ” If Barghest is on our side, the only opponent is Lancelot.

Oberon: If Muramasa and Grimm can keep her pinned down, the castle assault will be simple.

Oberon: Good work, you two.

Oberon: This way, we can reach Morgan's throne without losing a single person.

Oberon: Artoria's escort is Percival. Fujimaru's escort is Mash.

Oberon: Now, let's go! Let us first clear the way to the main gate!

--BATTLE--

Senji Muramasa: Damn it, I figured in addition to being a diversion, I'd charge in if I found an opening, but—

Senji Muramasa: What's with this wall!? This is way too bizarre! It's hot, it's cold, it's slippery, and it's bouncy!

Senji Muramasa: It's responding so lithely. Is this thing alive or what? Dammit!

Grimm the Wise: The ramparts of Camelot are made Orkney-style! They've got millennium grade oak in them!

Grimm the Wise: Even if you break them, they'll immediately regenerate, it's pointless! It'll be faster if we just pry open the East Gate!

Senji Muramasa: Our division here doesn't have the sort of tools for that! No choice but to hold out here!

Senji Muramasa: No, wait a minute. You're a Caster, aren't you? Hey Blue, can't you just make us a foothold so we can jump over the ramparts!?

Grimm the Wise: Oh! An oaken foothold against an oak tree! Sounds great to me, let's get them growing!

Grimm the Wise: Actually, it's too late to be throwing out good ideas now, Red! —Above us! Someone's coming!

Senji Muramasa: Ah! This sound—it's her!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Only the two Servants...? Then this must be the diversion. Too bad.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: But you're not lacking. And I'm acquainted with both of you. No need to bother introducing yourselves.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The continuation of our battle at Sheffield, and the continuation of our battle at the Great Pit.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Let's wrap both of those up here. Servants do tend to be tenacious after all.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I'll cut you both into equal parts like the good friends you are. Muramasa horizontally and Grimm vertically.

Senji Muramasa: We don't get along, he's just some old man I don't even know! Go ahead and shred him, I won't stop you for that!

Grimm the Wise: Shut up, I'm getting serious here, Muramasa! I won't stop you if you want to slice him up, though!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: See, you do get along. That is excellent. It makes cutting you up worth it.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: A worthy opponent is hard to come by. Especially for the strongest species, like me.

Grimm the Wise: Is that so? Then you'd best get serious too. You're the type of person who's never given it their all before, aren't you?

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Very well! Holding back would be a waste against opponents like you!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I am the Fairy Knight Lancelot! You makeshift Divine Spirits of pan-human history, I'll cut through the both of you!

--BATTLE--

Senji Muramasa: Got you!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: —! Why are they receiving the Foreign Magus's support!?

Grimm the Wise: It's not support, it's a countermeasure. I over-prepared before we began our offensive.

Grimm the Wise: I used my own magical energy to sustain the Servants that Fujimaru summoned.

Grimm the Wise: This is as far as that goes though. It really is tough to try and do that!

Grimm the Wise: Who would have thought, but it's nuts to try and maintain Heroic Spirits from different mythological systems all at once!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Hmm, you really are mage-like...I suppose you don't call yourself wise for nothing...

Grimm the Wise: What did you think I was, then!?

Fairy Knight Lancelot: I mean...you look like the type to start throwing spears...

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The fame of the Declaration of the Great God —Gungnir—reaches even Britain...and I thought we were both fellow Lancers...

Grimm the Wise: What the hell...? Muramasa, is she really the same Lancelot?

Senji Muramasa: I know it's hard to believe, but she's the real deal. This is her real self. A natural loner.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: ...(I think I'll kill Muramasa after this. )

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Wait...that's strange.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Breaching the Main Gate should be your priority. The Foreign Magus' role is to give [♂ his /♀ her] all at the main gate.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The fact that there was spare energy to share with Grimm means—

Round Table Army Soldier: Report, report! The Main Gate has been opened and the Giant Corps have broken through!

Round Table Army Soldier: Furthermore, Fairy Knight Barghest has surrendered!

Round Table Army Soldier: She has defected from the Queen's army! That ironclad fortress is now our ally!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Barghest...I knew you didn't seem very enthusiastic. So that's how it is...

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Very well...you win this round.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Fairy Knight Lancelot lost here.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: You will be able to report all three of Morgan's knights were vanquished by the Child of Prophecy's forces.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: But remember, that's just the official story.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: It's not like I actually lost or anything. Don't get the wrong idea.

Grimm the Wise: She's a dragon, alright...

Grimm the Wise: That strongest species who, despite showing her understanding of the human world, refuses to listen to a single word.

Grimm the Wise: Oh well, our job's over. I'll take the division and regroup with the main force, what about you?

Senji Muramasa: I'll join up with Fujimaru.

Senji Muramasa: Even if Barghest's on our side now, the siege is just starting.

Grimm the Wise: Is that so? Go wild, then.

Grimm the Wise: —Morgan's no pushover.

Grimm the Wise: According to the first Grimm, she's apparently never been outmatched before.

Grimm the Wise: No matter where, no matter who she's up against, as soon as she joins the battle, casualties ensue.

Grimm the Wise: It's merely a question of whether it'll be Morgan or her enemy.

Grimm the Wise: She's a woman of steel who won't stop until either her enemy is dead, or she herself has been killed.

Grimm the Wise: Leaving Artoria aside, Fujimaru and Mash are going to have a bad time with her.

Grimm the Wise: You go help them out. And in case of emergency...you know what to do, don't you?

Senji Muramasa: Naturally. Everyone keeps forgetting, but taking Morgan's head has always been my job.

--ARROW--

Percival: The main gate has been opened! Proceed to enter the castle town!

Percival: The Child of Prophecy will advance along the western route, suppressing enemy forces as she heads towards the castle!

Percival: Should anyone surrender, welcome them! Follow Fairy Knight Barghest's example.

Percival: Our objective is to establish a new Britain, one that can stand against the Great Calamity!

Percival: There is no need to hate one another! Do not throw away your lives in vain!

Knocknarea: Tch, that Percival! Hogging all the spotlight...!

Knocknarea: I can't lose either!

Knocknarea: Giant Corps, you did well breaching the main gate! But you must be at your limit already, fall back!

Knocknarea: Wind division, lend the Round Table Army a hand.

Knocknarea: Earth and Fang divisions, advance on the castle grounds as planned! Split into four and subjugate the Queen's army!

Knocknarea: I shall lead the King's Clan and advance along the eastern route! Ox division, advance!

Fujimaru 1: Knocknarea's on the front lines too!?

Fujimaru 2: (I had a feeling she would be, though! )

Knocknarea: Naturally. I can't set an example to my vassals if I don't put my own life on the line. If I fall from a stray arrow, then that's just how my fate goes.

Knocknarea: It's pointless to tell me not to push myself. After all, the same goes for you too, right?

Knocknarea: This is our only chance to confront Morgan in person. It's a race to see who gets into the castle first, Artoria!

Artoria: No need to worry about Knocknarea. Let's push forward.

Artoria: The main gate is still contested—

Barghest: I will suppress the Queen's forces stationed outside the walls.

Barghest: If they see a Fairy Knight defector, more men should surrender.

Barghest: Also, have a renowned soldier follow behind to keep an eye on me.

Barghest: That should put the rebel soldiers at ease.

Da Vinci: I suppose so. We know you won't betray us, but the same doesn't apply for the other soldiers.

Da Vinci: And this is a chance to make a name for yourself, you know? If you defeat the Queen, there's a chance you may be accepted by the new ruler.

Barghest: That won't be happening. I may have switched sides, but I have no intention of turning my blade against Her Majesty.

Barghest: I intend to be imprisoned once the battle ends. I will leave the rest to you and the clans.

Oberon: I see...so you're prepared to go that far. Then I shall keep an eye on you, Barghest.

Oberon: Someone in good graces with the Round Table Army to stand by your side. At the very least, the rebel forces won't see you as an enemy.

Oberon: However, please don't think this solves everything. Even if the main gate settles, there's still a lot that remains to be done.

Oberon: You're also feared by the highborn fairies of Camelot.

Oberon: What better way to make them submit than a single glare from you?

Barghest: Indeed, that is the right way. If it's against them, I'll brandish my horn as often as you please.

Barghest: But...I burned your forest down. Do you not loathe me, Oberon the rebel?

Oberon: I do. But that's not something I need to be remembering now.

Oberon: There are still others things that need to be done. Right, Percival?

Percival: Of course...

Percival: Let us answer the expectations of Fairy Knight Sir Barghest, who entrusted us with a new Britain.

Percival: 1st division, advance! The Child of Prophecy and the Foreign Magus are headed for the castle!

Percival: The fulfilment of the prophecy is within reach! In the name of the Round Table, let us escort the two of them safely!

Fairy Knight Lancelot: The main gate has been taken...

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Only the innocent shall pass, huh? But, not a single fairy without sin exists in Britain.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: That gate acknowledges this. It is her resolve to accept them, sinner or not.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: In other words, Morgan's one and only mercy. And they've trampled on it.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: In that case, there's no need for us to hold back either.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: Crush the rebel cells on the castle grounds one by one, then execute Barghest the traitor.

Fairy Knight Lancelot: That is the role of a Fairy Knight. I'll end this in twenty minutes—

Fairy Knight Lancelot: This wind is...from Aurora...

Fairy Knight Lancelot: What is she saying...?

--BATTLE--

Mash: So this is Camelot...the city that Tonelico— no, Queen Morgan built—

Mash: No, this is no time to be in awe. There's a colossal stockpile of magical energy...!

Mash: I've seen several magical reactor cores before, but it's no exaggeration to say this surpasses them all!

Da Vinci: Yes, it truly is the furthest end yet center of the world.

Da Vinci: A phenomenon comparable to the “Tower of the Furthest End” that manifested in the Holy City Camelot...

Da Vinci: Even if the tide of battle is in our favor, Morgan still possesses the trump card known as the “Holy Lance”.

Da Vinci: Don't let your guards down. If it comes down to it, there's the possibility that she'll use Rhongomyniad.

Da Vinci: We need to make it into the castle before she annihilates the entire city!

Fujimaru 1: That's right...!

Mash: Roger! I won't let Morgan do that. After all, this is the city of the Round Table, Camelot!

Round Table Army Soldier: Rhongomyniad...?

Round Table Army Soldier: I beg your pardon, Lady Da Vinci. But, what exactly is Rhongomyniad?

Round Table Army Soldier: Is that the name of a Fairy Knight? I've never heard the name before...

Fujimaru 1: What...?

Fujimaru 2: Rhongomyniad is, you know...

Da Vinci: We're talking about the spears placed in front of Camelot...is the Round Table Army not aware of those?

Da Vinci: It's a light composed of an immense amount of magical energy, capable of annihilating the surface on a scale close to that of the Great Pit's, although not quite that much—

Da Vinci: No, I see. So that's how it is.

Da Vinci: No one in Britain has witnessed the light of Rhongomyniad before.

Da Vinci: Morgan never used the Holy Lance during her conquest of Britain. There's not a single trace of its use in Britain!

Fujimaru 1: !

Fujimaru 2: But Muramasa said he was sure they were there!

Da Vinci: That's probably the case...No doubt, Rhongomyniad is actually there.

Da Vinci: However, not once did she use it. Morgan subjugated Britain with her own might alone.

Da Vinci: In that case, what's the point of the Existence Tax?

Da Vinci: If it's not for the sake of using Rhongomyniad, then what is all that magical energy being used for...?

Clerk Meldick: Fairy Knight Sir Barghest has surrendered to the rebellion. It would appear she has abandoned her post as guardian of the Main Gate.

Clerk Meldick: Fairy Knight Sir Lancelot has taken to the skies above Camelot. Her current whereabouts are unknown.

Clerk Meldick: There are no reports of her defeat at the hands of the rebellion. It is assumed that she has disobeyed orders and deserted in the face of the enemy.

Clerk Meldick: The rebel forces have occupied 60% of Camelot. Of the Queen's knights, 42 are still battleworthy.

Clerk Meldick: The entrance to the castle has been cut off via use of a “mobile section”, but it will likely be breached eventually.

Morgan: —

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: What a disaster, the main gate has fallen!? And Barghest has defected, to boot!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Would you look at that, turns out she was just a lowly black dog! Giving her land made her forget her place!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Knocknarea has won over the giants! To think those things would be here, this is the problem with the northern fairies!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Those country bumpkins don't know the first thing about politics or economics! Oh, my prized business is going to be ruined!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Indemnity, that's right, indemnity! I am insured! I need to claim my insurance from Her Majesty!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Sir Lancelot's gone too!? Then who's going to beat them back!?

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: I don't want Knocknarea to get here! I've been bad-mouthing her on the daily!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: She'll definitely kill me! Oh, I wonder if the Child of Prophecy will save me then! She will, won't she!?

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Maybe...maybe...

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: The Queen's army is going to lose...? I-if they do, what will happen to we highborn fairies...?

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Queen Morgan! O wise queen, what shall we do!?

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: S-shall we surrender now!? Won't they stop if Her Majesty offers herself up!?

Morgan: —It is a matter of course. Your fears and worries are warranted.

Morgan: Barghest has defected. Lancelot has disobeyed orders.

Morgan: The main gate has been breached, and it is only a matter of time until they take the castle, as well.

Morgan: Playtime with the Fairy Knights is over now. As you wish, I will change my approach.

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: Ohh! Her Majesty has left the throne! How wonderful! As expected of Her Majesty!

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: But...what will she do now?

Fairies Gathered Around the Throne: The rebels won't stop just because she got up from her throne, you know?

Clerk Meldick: —The officials shall remain silent. Fall prostrate with your backs against the wall. Weep and offer praise.

Clerk Meldick: Her Majesty departs for the battlefield. The battlefield shall now belong to Her Majesty.

Morgan: Now then—it's been 2,000 years since I have played seriously. I suppose I shall be careful not to checkmate them on the very first move.

--ARROW--

Fujimaru 1: Strange...we still haven't made it to the castle?

Fujimaru 2: We got straight there during our audience...

Percival: This is...what my sist–no, what I heard about in rumors. It appears to be...the “mobile section” of Camelot.

Percival: It's said that the ramparts of Camelot and some of its buildings can change positions.

Artoria: Oh, so that's why! I had a feeling the city's layout was different from the last time I came!

Da Vinci: I see. I thought it was one large building after another, but it looks like this is a wall in itself.

Da Vinci: On closer inspection, there appears to be rails running along the ground. Quite impressive, even if it just slides sideways.

Mash: Then this means...we won't be able to use the route to the castle noted on this map anymore.

Mash: If she can move the buildings, she can also disguise the entrance to the castle as a dead end.

Percival: Ah! That's exactly right. Naturally, she must have sealed it off.

Percival: Thank you, Mash, that was a great help. I was earnestly about to look for the entrance like a fool.

Mash: N-no, it's nothing worth thanking me for...

Mash: (The Percival of this Lostbelt...I haven't had the time to tell him...)

Mash: (But he's different from how I imagined Percival to be...it almost feels like...he's the same age as me...)

Artoria: I guess you shouldn't judge by appearances. In that case, over there! It should be over there!

Artoria: The magical signature is the densest there! Either way, the throne's in that direction!

Percival: Understood. Etwar, please relay this to the other squadrons.

Percival: Camelot's terrain is shifting. Tell them to not blindly follow the map.

Soldiers of the Wind Clan: You're fine with an unencrypted, open broadcast, right? Then that's an easy task. Leave it to me.

Fujimaru 1: Huh? There's a wind coming from Etwar...

Artoria: The “Voice of the Wind”. A specialty of the Wind Clan. They can have the winds carry their voices.

Artoria: But it's not a particularly confidential means of communication, since other fairies will be able to hear you as well.

Artoria: I think only powerful Wind Clan fairies are capable of using the “Voice of the Wind” to address specific individuals.

Da Vinci: In other words, it's not much good for plotting or scheming. However, it's perfect for sharing information like we're doing now.

Da Vinci: Knocknarea will overhear too, but that's a different matter. Right now, our priority is to enter the castle.

Percival: Yes. Let's settle things before the Queen's knights can restore their formations.

Fujimaru 1: —Hold on a minute.

Fujimaru 2: Does it also rain ash with the wind?

Mash: Oh! Artoria!

Artoria: Mash!?

???: That shield, the Round Table, is it? I see the mages of pan-human history know neither fear nor respect.

???: That place where heroes gather, the accumulation of the will to protect the country.

???: To use it as one's personal arms. Even I would not think of such sacrilege.

???: Or perhaps–that is exactly what pan-human history is.

???: From the start, it has never bothered choosing the means to its survival.

Artoria: No way–out of nowhere, in the middle of the city...!?

Fujimaru 1: No doubt about it...that's Morgan, Queen of the Fairy Kingdom!

Morgan: It is precisely because it is the middle of the city. There is no need to lie in wait for insects.

Morgan: The throne of Camelot is the cornerstone of the Fairy Kingdom. I shall not allow it to be tainted by blood.

Morgan: Child of Prophecy, Artoria. Magus of Chaldea, Fujimaru.

Morgan: And—

Morgan: The Servant with the Saint Graph of Galahad the Heavenly Knight.

Morgan: You did well completing the pilgrimage. I shall praise you.

Morgan: The six clans have once again arrived at their moment of reckoning. Salvation shall be granted to all the fairies of Britain.

Morgan: However—hmph, I feel contempt at the depths of my heart.

Morgan: The Pilgrim's Bell is but an ephemeral matter.

Morgan: The fairies will forget soon enough. And with it, your efforts, your suffering, your anger, your grief.

Morgan: You should have realized that when you rang your second bell. Yet you did not abandon your pilgrimage.

Morgan: You have chosen righteousness over this Britain turned lost. You are fine with that, yes?

Artoria: Of course I'm not fine with it...Don't speak to me about things like righteousness.

Artoria: I was only born because you abandoned your duty.

Artoria: If you had seen it through, that girl would never have had reason to become king.

Artoria: I don't know about the original sin of the six clans, nor do I care about it either. I just want to complete my mission and be at ease.

Artoria: The origin of the Fairy Kingdom and Tonelico's suffering both have nothing to do with me!

Artoria: I used to feel like there's no way I could take you on, but things are different now! Fight me, Morgan!

Artoria: As for what comes after—I'll worry about that when the time comes.

Artoria: I don't know what is right. I don't want to see or know my fate either.

Artoria: Britain's future and the outside world are both beyond me. Unlike you—

Artoria: Unlike you, I don't have that sort of upstanding ambition.

Artoria: I just can't lose! That's all that I believe in!

Morgan: I see. You have not grasped your true identity, even after your pilgrimage.

Morgan: Come then. I will bring an end to that foolish destiny.

Morgan: Artoria. You who were my bitter enemy in pan-human history.

Morgan: You cannot go anywhere. You cannot change anything.

Morgan: That is why I shall grant you mercy. If you cannot change it, then I shall.

Morgan: It is time you went back to being a pitiful village girl. You will never reach the Site of Selection.

Morgan: What is Chaldea? What is the Rayshift, and for what purpose is it provided?

Narration: The storm swept in at a moment's notice. It was a curtain that was abruptly lowered unto the stage.

Spriggan: No. There is no need to return to the throne. I'm afraid you have no right to do so.

Morgan: —You're the one who directed Woodwose here.

Morgan: Do you tire of living, Spriggan? To think you'd seek your own downfall.

Spriggan: No, no. My lifespan is always a source of concern for me, but this is a different matter altogether.

Spriggan: This time, I came with an assurance of victory. On the contrary, I'd even say now is the perfect opportunity.

Spriggan: Your Fairy Kingdom has been wonderful.

Spriggan: There has been no other instance of a single monarch reigning for 2,000 years.

Spriggan: You can hardly call it a country if there's neither prosperity nor decline.

Morgan: —You underestimate me.

Morgan: Even if only my head remains, I shall not fall to the rank and file.

Morgan: —Baobhan...Sith.

Girl with Limbs Rotting Off: “Thank you, Lady Witch. Thank you for all your hard work. ”

Girl with Limbs Rotting Off: “Everyone speaks ill of you, but I'm grateful to you, Lady Witch. ”
